text: Patient: Tomorrow I’m going to this local one. I have a schedule with Dr. ___in January because the last neurologist that I saw, the one that put the catheter in, told me the catheter should not be taken out in less than four to six weeks. It should be replaced in every four to six weeks if necessary. Doctor: Sure. Patient: So when I talked to ___, he said okay, then come in January and then we’ll that procedure. So I don’t know if I should go there. I don’t even know what else he can do. I didn’t have chance to talk to him personally. I talked to nurse and she did not explain correctly. Looks like he can’t do anything for me except the nurse is taking catheter out and putting it in. So what other treatments he’s going to give me, I don’t know. Doctor: Dr. ____ or Patient: Dr. ____. Doctor: And the issue really is we’d like to get the catheter out and sort of when is your bladder strong enough to take it out, if we’ve shrunk the cancer with the hormone therapy – Patient: Um hum. Doctor: - is there enough of a channel for you to pee on our own? Doctor: So all of that – Patient: Okay. Doctor: - is what urologists do. Patient: Right, I know. So anyway, I have it scheduled.

text: Patient: Hmm. Doctor: That trial is going to take the immune system idea to the max which is okay if, more importantly, the reason is, not to oversell, but one of the things with prostate cancer that we see is, when you look at other cancers under the microscope, you see the immune system trying at least. You see the immune cell in that. And without seen to be completely effective, but sometimes these immune drugs we give give enough of an edge that they work. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: When you look at prostate cancer under the microscope, it’s like there’s a force field. There’s no immune cells around. So the immune system is totally blind. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: So we wondered that when we give these new immune drugs, they don’t work because there’s really no end to treatment, no soldiers in there to stimulate what’s not there. Patient: I see. Doctor: So how, so a lot of the research is how do we get those cells attractive- Patient: Um hum. Doctor: to go in the cancer? And the most extreme way would be give you a new immune system. Give you somebody else’s immune system where those cancers were foreign. Patient: I see. Doctor: Uh so right now you’re eligible for that. Maybe put that on the back burner. The one thing that would make you ineligible is going on chemotherapy.

text: Patient: My hip primarily, the hip and lumbar region. Doctor: And that’s your right hip? Patient: Right hip, yeah and then that was ten doses and the lower femur, five doses of treatments. Doctor: And how are you feeling? Patient: Pretty good. Doctor: How’s your pain? Patient: No pain. There’s just a little; I know my right hip is there. You know I know what the sensation is. Doctor: So the radiation helped? Patient: Yes, I think so, yes. Doctor: But you still need to take the opioids. Patient: Yeah, yeah, but not as much. I’ve cut down. Doctor: So the OxyContin was two times a day and now you’re once a day.

text: Patient: Right. (Laughs) Doctor: Okay? Because I don’t want to go too far with the numbness, huh, if that’s a possibility. Patient: Okay. Doctor: One of the things about the positive thing about the vitamin C is there is some bit of the people get less numbness. Huh, normally after three or four doses of the chemotherapy, huh, we have a sense of whether it’s helping. Your PSA may be lower. Your pain may be better. Huh, huh, those are sort of some of the clues. Okay? Huh, if we feel like it’s, you are getting better, we’re going to keep going as far as ten treatments. Huh, if after three or four doses, your pain’s worse, your PSA is higher, huh, I might even get scans after the fourth cycle to follow your lymph nodes. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: Huh, because if your PSA is going up, and your lymph nodes are getting bigger, we’re not going to keep giving you the chemotherapy if it’s causing all those side effects. Patient: Right. Doctor: Okay? So we’ll check probably after about twelve weeks, huh, about how it’s going. Huh, but our job will be to cheer lead you through the first three to four cycles, huh, adjusting the dose if you’re having side effects and they’re too severe. But most people are able to get through it. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Huh, so my recommendation is that we stop the abiraterone, continue the prednisone. If you’re interested in the clinical trial, I can at least start with, huh, printing it out for you, and letting you read it, and see how often you need to be here, let the nurse know that you’re potentially interested, and she can, huh, do insurance clearance. Patient: Okay. Doctor: So if they say your insurance is not going to pay for it, the decision’s made. Patient: Right.

text: Patient: Um, hum. Doctor: and twelve months later your PSA is stabilizes Patient: Um, hum. Doctor: Okay. Patient: Um, hum. And that is Doctor: In your case, if I would have to guess with your PSA track record – Patient: Um, hum. Doctor: - your PSA was a fourteen in September and then it was twenty-eight January. So in a four-month period your PSA went up one hundred percent. It doubled. Patient: Um, hum. Doctor: So based on that trajectory, if I had to guess, your PSA is still at the same place, so to speak, it will take about half that amount of time for your PSA to go about fifty percent. So if it goes - you’re expected to go up fifty percent … for a year, two years Patient: Um, hum. Doctor: So that’s the general, overall, design of the trial. And um because the trial involves radiation therapy being delivered by a radiology oncologist. And would and the ORIOLE study as they call it, is being run by one of the radiology oncologists called Dr. T. You’ll see his name here. And, the way that we would precede, if you wanted me to, is to after we have this conversation… to give you the consent form, read it very carefully.

text: Patient: Yeah. Doctor: It almost would require us putting you back on it, having demonstrated it doesn’t work, and then adding this drug, which is kind of weird. Occasionally, however, we have seen men after testosterone because potentially you could respond to enzalutamide. I don’t know. Patient: Yeah. Doctor: So that’s a little bit confusing but that’s another possible trial. Patient: That’s the extent, enzalutamide? Doctor: Yeah, right. So I mean you didn’t respond. Patient: Well I mean the, the PSA went up a little bit. It went from- Doctor: With the scans. Yeah. Patient: Yeah. Doctor: Uh and the third trial we have which is the most extreme one, we’re also doing bone marrow transplant trial, which um is way out there. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: Uh we have two men we’ve treated now, your age or younger. Uh that would require you to live here for a couple of months, and it would require a donor, a female, like a daughter, or sister, or cousin.

Doctor-Patient-Conversation-Analysis-pos.text: Thank you for your valuable contributions to our study! Our goal is to understand how doctors can communicate better with patients by looking at different perceptions of the doctors’ qualities. Understanding your personal experiences with the medical system will help us to contextualize your responses. We invite you to share insights by answering the following questions. Your answers to these questions are strictly confidential and anonymous.
Doctor-Patient-Conversation-Analysis-pos.displayed_text: Thank you for your valuable contributions to our study! Our goal is to understand how doctors can communicate better with patients by looking at different perceptions of the doctors’ qualities. Understanding your personal experiences with the medical system will help us to contextualize your responses. We invite you to share insights by answering the following questions. Your answers to these questions are strictly confidential and anonymous.
